bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 19, 1946

div1.p: Hench discusses the history of the Kissinger family trying to obtain more pension money, including a plea for funeral expenses from Ida Kissinger for her husband.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 19, 1946
div1.opener:
August 19, 1946
General Jefferson R. Kean
2804 North Street, North West
Georgetown, Washington, C. C.
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
I have a letter from Mrs. Kissinger telling me a few details
about the death of Mr. Kissinger. As I anticipated, in the letter she
also brought up the matter of a pension. She states, “We had supposed
that I would get the same annuity. Well, it seems that such is not the
case. I think you might help out by writing General Kean. All I want
or ask is that they give me enough to pay hospital and funeral expenses,
and that is little enough for one who suffered what he did. I am not
very well____”

I have, in recent years, not been too happy at receiving
letters from the Kissingers as in almost every letter they would include
a rather poorly disguised hint that they would be glad to receive money.
I have no doubt that they have been under unusual expenses, but much of
that expense was unnecessary. You will remember that you and I advised
Mrs. Kissinger long ago to send Mr. Kissinger to an army hospital. They
preferred to keep him at home for quite awhile, and I believe they had
to have extra help. Certainly, Mr. Kissinger should have known the
circumstances about his pension, and should have been preparing all these
years for his death and for the future care of his wife. I think that
she has several children. I believe they sold their Huntington home
and bought a little house in Florida, so that she must have a little
property. I do hope that she won't start a campaign that will embarrass
you and me and his other friends. In answering her letter, I have
urged that she write to Washington to find out the circumstances of his
annuity. If she really is in need of money to pay funeral expenses,
don't you suppose the local Red Cross or American Legion could come to
her help? Between the importunings of Lambert and the Kissingers I get
a bit weary at times; and, of course, if I feel that way, how much more
must you have felt that way all these years. In my letter to
Mrs. Kissinger, I tried to encourage her not to bother you, but I have
no doubt that she will write to you in time.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alp
